prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Search for Methanol CH3OH toward HD 163296
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: The proposed science goal is to detect methanol. More specificaly, we intent to stack multiple transitions of this molecule by summing up their intensities.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We intend to detect CH3OH by stacking 15 transitions of methanol. This ALMA-OT science goal will be achieved with 4 spectral windows (2 basebands) of 234.375 MHz, which will therefore cover a bandwidth of 0.937GHz.
In addition, we set one baseband of 1875.0 MHz for continuum purpose. Also, the continuum peak flux densities are based on the SMA observations of these sources by Qi et et al. (2013).

We propose to image CH3OH by stacking 15 transitions of methanol in band 4 in the C36-3 configuration resulting into an angular resolution of 0.8".
High angular resolution is requiered since at the present time methanol has not been detected yet in disks and therefore, its emitting zone is unknown.
Based on previous observations of the proposed source we estimate that the source size should be less than 4''.

We intend to stack 15 transitions of methanol by summing up their intensities. The proposed observations will allow us to go, reasonably, deeper in the detection of these species, since based on our model, we estimate that the S/N increases by at least a factor of about 4.
Based on a Cycle 2 ALMA detection of H2CO toward TW-Hya (P.I. Bergin) and assuming that methanol is a fraction of 5 less intense than H2CO, we estimate a peak line flux density of 15 mJy/beam. We thus ask for a signal-to-noise ratio of 10 which will result on a signal-to-noise ratio of 40 on the resulted stacked line. We add significant margin given the uncertainty in our estimates.
Likewise, we ask for spectral resolution of about 1.0 km/s in order to reduce the potential confusion, since this stacking method requires lines that are not contaminated by the emission from other molecules.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Search for Formic Acid HCOOH toward HD 163296
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: The proposed science goal is to detect formic acid. More specificaly, we intent to stack multiple transitions of this molecule by summing up their intensities.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We intend to detect HCOOH by stacking 7 transitions of formic acid. This ALMA-OT science goal will be achieved with 6 spectral windows (3 basebands) of 234.375 MHz, which will therefore cover a bandwidth of 1.406GHz.
In addition, we set one baseband of 1875.0 MHz for continuum purpose. Also, the continuum peak flux densities are based on the SMA observations of these sources by Qi et et al. (2013).

We propose to image HCOOH by stacking 7 transitions of formic acid in band 4 in the C36-3 configuration resulting nto an angular resolution of 0.8".
High angular resolution is requiered since at the present time formic acid has not been detected yet in disks and therefore, its emitting zone is unknown.
Based on previous observations of the proposed source we estimate that the source size should be less than 4''.

We intend to stack 7 transitions of formic acid by summing up their intensities. The proposed observations will allow us to go, reasonably, deeper in the detection of these species, since based on our model, we estimate that the S/N increases by at least a factor of about 4.
Based on a Cycle 2 ALMA detection of H2CO toward TW-Hya (P.I. Bergin) and assuming that methanol is a fraction of 5 less intense than H2CO, we estimate a peak line flux density of 15 mJy/beam. We thus ask for a signal-to-noise ratio of 10 which will result on a signal-to-noise ratio of 40 on the resulted stacked line. We add significant margin given the uncertainty in our estimates.
Likewise, we ask for spectral resolution of about 1.0 km/s in order to reduce the potential confusion, since this stacking method requires lines that are not contaminated by the emission from other molecules.

We intend to detect CH3OH by stacking 15 transitions of methanol. This ALMA-OT science goal will be achieved with 4 spectral windows (2 basebands) of 234.375 MHz, which will therefore cover a bandwidth of 0.937GHz.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Search for Formic Acid HCOOH toward TW Hydrae
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: The proposed science goal is to detect formic acid. More specificaly, we intent to stack multiple transitions of this molecule by summing up their intensities.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We intend to detect HCOOH by stacking 7 transitions of formic acid. This ALMA-OT science goal will be achieved with 6 spectral windows (3 basebands) of 234.375 MHz, which will therefore cover a bandwidth of 1.406GHz.
In addition, we set one baseband of 1875.0 MHz for continuum purpose. Also, the continuum peak flux densities are based on the SMA observations of these sources by Qi et et al. (2013).

We propose to image HCOOH by stacking 7 transitions of formic acid in band 4 in the C36-3 configuration resulting nto an angular resolution of 0.8".
High angular resolution is requiered since at the present time formic acid has not been detected yet in disks and therefore, its emitting zone is unknown.
Based on previous observations of the proposed source we estimate that the source size should be less than 4''.

We intend to stack 7 transitions of formic acid by summing up their intensities. The proposed observations will allow us to go, reasonably, deeper in the detection of these species, since based on our model, we estimate that the S/N increases by at least a factor of about 4.
Based on a Cycle 2 ALMA detection of H2CO toward TW-Hya (P.I. Bergin) and assuming that methanol is a fraction of 5 less intense than H2CO, we estimate a peak line flux density of 15 mJy/beam. We thus ask for a signal-to-noise ratio of 10 which will result on a signal-to-noise ratio of 40 on the resulted stacked line. We add significant margin given the uncertainty in our estimates.
Likewise, we ask for spectral resolution of about 1.0 km/s in order to reduce the potential confusion, since this stacking method requires lines that are not contaminated by the emission from other molecules.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: One of the most important questions of astrochemistry is how, when and whether complex organic molecules (i.e that contain more than 6 atoms) and potentially prebiotic molecules are formed and could this have a bearing on the origin of life on Earth? In that context, we are focussing on the two following key molecules: methanol (CH3OH) and formic acid (HCOOH), that are precursors of larger species, including potentially prebiotic molecules. Those key molecules have been detected toward star-forming regions and comets, but not in protoplanetary disks. Nevertheless, these species are likely expected to be present in those environments. In the proposed observations, we intend to detect both methanol and formic acid by using an advanced method where we will stack multiple transitions of methanol and formic acid by summing up their intensities, respectively.
